text: [Music]
Yeah, we have three candidates. We have
a rep the definite Republican candidate
McCain. We have two Democratic
candidates, Barack Obama and Hillary
Clinton. Well, I certainly wouldn't
choose McCain because McCain is a war
hawk. McCain, I mean, this this war in
Iraq is one of the most disastrous
things the United States has ever done
for our people and certainly for the
people of Iraq. So McCain wanting to
continue the war that that Bush started
five years ago. McCain is absolutely
repulsive to me between Clinton and
Obama. Well, both of them have promised
to end the war, but I must say their
proposals for bringing the troops out of
Iraq are rather half-hearted and and uh
you know, they talk about keeping troops
there or Barack Obama says, "Well, let's
take out of Iraq, send troops to
Afghanistan." They haven't, neither of
them has shaken what Barack Obama
rightly called the mindset that led to
the Iraq war. The mindset is a mindset
which sees war and military intervention
as a solution. Neither of them has
shaken that. So, uh, so I'm not happy,
as you can see, with any of the
candidates. When I get to the voting
booth, I'll be forced against my will
because I want somebody else other than
those three. I'll be forced against my
will to make a choice. And I'll probably
choose uh Obama because in many ways he
represents something really different,
uh a multi-racial person who is
supported by a large number of young and
enthusiastic people. uh and who may that
is these young enthusiastic people may
uh if he is elected become a force that
he has to reckon with uh and will push
him in a better direction than he has
shown so
[Music]
far. Well, I think Americans need
to recognize that they uh cannot depend
on our political system to do the right
thing. That Americans need to recognize
that they have to create local
institutions, organizations, town halls.
uh they have to create grassroots
organizations
uh which all over the country will uh
speak to the national
politicians in order to bring about a
change both in foreign and domestic
policy. In other words, I think
Americans need to get to realize that
they cannot limit their participation as
citizens to going to the polls every
several years to vote. that they must
participate every day. Uh and uh I mean
Henry David Thorough said it, we must
vote uh with our arms, with our legs,
with our feet, with our whole bodies.
And by that he meant uh people should be
active and involved uh every day of the
year if we are really going to have a
democratic society.
[Music]
